Text: DC Jews just appearing outside downtown mosque at midday prayer. Someone posted on Facebook and strangers just showing up https://t.co/wVYLDqwgYT
IHRA_Explanation:
The tweet refers to Jewish individuals appearing at a mosque and does not express any form of hatred, discrimination, or harmful intent towards them. It appears to be a factual observation without any overtly antisemitic content or calls for harm.

The IHRA's definition of antisemitism involves expressions of hatred, which this tweet lacks. Instead, it focuses on an interaction between two groups in a specific location, without targeting Jews negatively. Therefore, the tweet does not meet the criteria for being considered antisemitic under the IHRA's working definition.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet in question describes a specific event with minimal context beyond the presence of some Jewish individuals at a mosque. It does not engage in any form of discrimination, prejudice, or harmful stereotype-making against Jews. The tweet is neutral and does not attempt to generalize about all Jews or link them to negative stereotypes related to anti-Semitism as defined by the JDA.

Text: This is what the right has accomplished, brought to a more absurd level by Trump. Like some others, he can‚Äôt see American Jews as anything but an extension of Israel. https://t.co/R79npgeCag
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet associates Trump with seeing American Jews as part of Israel, which aligns with IHRA's definition. It uses a stereotype that equates Jewish identity with support for Israel, potentially implying exclusion or villainy towards Jews in America. This stereotyping and association fit within the criteria of antisemitism by targeting individuals based on their perceived connection to another group.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet aligns with several points from the JDA's guidelines regarding antisemitism. Specifically, it reflects B.7 by suggesting that American Jews are solely responsible for certain actions attributed to Trump and others within the "right," positioning them as agents of Israel without considering their own national interests or identities. Additionally, it touches on B.9 by implying that non-Israeli Jews (American Jews in this context) are more loyal to Israel than their own countries, which is a form of stereotyping and discrimination. These elements together constitute antisemitism according to the JDA's definition.

Text: The claim that Jews/Judaism & Zionists/Zionism are the same thing or interchangeable, or that all Jews are responsible for the actions of Israel is in fact one of the clearest antisemitic tropes around.\n\nSo you keep doing you, ‚ÄòIsrael Advocacy Movement‚Äô, you‚Äôre doing a great job. https://t.co/I3ZmiagGsj
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet contains elements that touch upon antisemitic themes but does not fully adhere to the IHRA definition. It makes a stereotypical claim about Jews being interchangeable with Zionists and suggests that all Jews are responsible for Israel's actions, which aligns with antisemitism by perpetuating stereotypes and generalizations. However, the latter part of the tweet directs criticism towards "Israel Advocacy Movement" without directly addressing or critiquing Jews, thus not fully embodying the essence of antisemitism according to the IHRA definition.
JDA_Explanation:
The tweet employs antisemitic tropes by equating Jews with Zionists and suggesting all Jews are responsible for Israel's actions. This aligns with the JDA definition of antisemitism as it involves lumping Jews into broad categories tied to negative stereotypes, which is a core aspect of antisemitic ideology outlined in guidelines 6 and 7.

The tweet uses classical antisemitic symbols and images (Zionists/Zionism) to negatively portray Jewish identity, thereby contributing to antisemitism. This approach reduces the complexity of Jewish heritage by associating it with harmful stereotypes about responsibility for state actions, which is a recognized form of antisemitism under the JDA framework.

Text: Jews will have their citizenship revoked will be reinstated https://t.co/G7hkjpDQHL
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet "Jews will have their citizenship revoked will be reinstated" targets Jews specifically by mentioning citizenship changes. This aligns with the IHRA's definition of antisemitism, particularly in terms of discrimination based on Jewish identity (denying rights). While it doesn't explicitly express hatred or conspiracies, it involves denying a fundamental right (citizenship), which can be seen as a form of antisemitic discrimination.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet discusses citizenship revocation and reinstatement in a manner that could be interpreted as targeting the general population of Jews, without specific context. According to the JDA, this aligns with guidelines 2 (using stereotypes or ideas about evil) and 10 (denying Jewish rights). The general statement about citizenship could imply discrimination against Jewish people, touching on sensitive issues related to their status and rights, which may resonate with existing antisemitic narratives.

Text: The Shoes on the Danube Memorial (2005), honours the Jews who were killed by fascist militiamen in Budapest in WWII. "They were ordered to take off their shoes, and were shot at the edge of the water so that their bodies...were carried away."\n#HolocaustRemembranceDay https://t.co/mi4lOFBYs0
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet is about the Shoes on the Danube Memorial, which honors Jews who were victims of fascist actions during WWII. It provides factual information without any antisemitic content such as hate speech or demonization of Jews.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet is not antisemitic according to the JDA because it honors the memory of Jews who were victims of fascism without promoting negative stereotypes or criticism of Israel/Palestine. It focuses on remembrance and justice, which aligns with non-antisemitic forms of expression.

Text:
Rep. @tomemmer, chairman of the @NRCC, sent a letter to GOP party members saying that rich Jews are buying Congress.

This is antisemitism. At a time of rising white nationalism, it's dangerous. And it's the official platform of the Republican Party.

https://t.co/9yg13LeX0J
IHRA_Explanation:
This tweet presents antisemitic content. It uses a slur against Jews by associating them with economic influence in Congress, which can be interpreted as hatred toward a specific group. Additionally, it ties into a broader context of white nationalism, reinforcing harmful stereotypes and aligning with antisemitic rhetoric.

---

**Analysis of IHRA Definition:**

The tweet from Rep. Tomummer accuses rich Jews of purchasing Congress, labeling this action as antisemitism. According to the IHRA definition, antisemitism involves targeting Jews with hatred, often expressed through negative stereotypes or slurs that imply a collective responsibility for societal issues. The tweet's accusation against Jews based on economic status and political influence aligns with such harmful stereotypes.

Moreover, within the context of rising white nationalism, the tweet reflects anti-Semitic narratives and aligns with the Republican Party's conservative platform, which has been associated with antisemitic statements in the past. This makes the tweet particularly dangerous as it reinforces discriminatory and hateful rhetoric against Jews.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet employs the stereotype of "rich Jews" controlling Congress, a harmful generalization that essentializes Jews based on their assumed wealth and political influence. This aligns with JDA guidelines, particularly the use of symbols or stereotypes targeting Jews (guideline 2) and reflects antisemitic ideology by projecting negative characteristics onto a specific group.

Text: "Then came the Jews round about him, and said unto him, How long dost thou make us to doubt? If thou be the Christ, tell us plainly." ~John 10:24 #Bible #God #Hope
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet does not directly reference Israel or make Holocaust-related claims, so it doesn't explicitly fall under IHRA's antisemitic definitions related to those topics. However, the use of "Jews" in a religious context could be interpreted as perpetuating negative stereotypes about Jewish people within certain religious traditions where exclusionary labels are used. While this interpretation is possible, it depends on the broader context and intent behind the tweet. Without explicit references to antisemitic themes or historical persecution, the tweet may not fully align with IHRA's definition of antisemitism.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet does not appear to be antisemitic according to the JDA definition. It references a biblical passage, John 10:24, which is presented neutrally without any discriminatory language or stereotype use of Jews. There is no indication that the tweet implies Jews are responsible for any wrongdoing, nor does it target them as a group with negative connotations. Therefore, based on guidelines B and C, the tweet is not antisemitic in nature.

Text: @airsilk @IlhanMN Hates Jews, hates God, hates white people, hates non Muslims, hates America, the nasty incest having tramp just hates everything.
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet in question uses language that targets Jews and other groups, making broad and general statements about their hates. While the IHRA definition focuses on hatred towards Jews, the tweet extends this to other groups without proper context or justification. This stereotyping and generalization align with antisemitism as defined by IHRA, which includes targeting Jewish individuals or communities inappropriately. The tweet's aggressive tone and lack of evidence-based claims further support its classification as antisemitic according to the provided definition.
JDA_Explanation: According to the Jerusalem Declaration on Antisemitism (JDA), antisemitism is defined as discrimination or prejudice against Jews as a group or their institutions. The tweet in question uses strong negative language targeting multiple groups, including Jews, but it does not specifically target Jewish people or their institutions beyond general hateful remarks about haters. While the broader context of IlhanMN's statements could align with antisemitist ideologies, this particular tweet is too generalized and does not meet the JDA's specific criteria for antisemitism, which requires targeting Jews as a group. Therefore, it is not considered antisemitic under the given definition.

Text: I have NEVER been able to figure out WHY Non-Jews ''HATE'' Jewish People so much.\n#FoxNews https://t.co/c0qIN1asHJ
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet poses a general accusation that non-Jews "HATE" Jewish people, which aligns with the IHRA definition of antisemitism as it involves expressing hatred towards Jews. While it doesn't explicitly target Israel or use specific examples, it falls under the broader category of antisemitic expressions by making broad claims about hatred without justification.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet does not contain any antisemitic content as defined by the Jerusalem Declaration on Antisemitism (JDA). It is simply a general inquiry about societal perceptions and does not involve discrimination, hate speech, or any form of antisemitism.

Text: U.S. ambassador urges Jews in Germany to wear kippa, not conceal identity | The Jerusalem post https://t.co/f1SP3WC2fs
IHRA_Explanation:
The tweet in question employs language that could be interpreted as stigmatizing Jewish individuals by urging them to adopt a specific practice (wearing a kippa) without consent, which aligns with antisemitic behavior. While the IHRA definition does not explicitly forbid such actions if they are not part of a broader conspiracy or discriminatory campaign targeting Jews specifically, the act of advising on how to present oneself could be seen as imposing negative stereotypes or practices that may contribute to antisemitism.

The IHRA defines antisemitism as hatred or systemic prejudice directed at Jews. The tweet targets Jewish people by suggesting a specific behavior (wearing a kippa) as a form of identification, which could perpetuate negative stereotypes and potentially harm Jewish communities. This aligns with the IHRA's criteria for antisemitism, particularly regarding antisemitic discrimination and conspiracy theories. Therefore, while the tweet may not directly accuse Jews of conspiracies or actions against humanity, its nature and content could still be classified as antisemitic under the given framework.

In conclusion, the tweet is considered antisemitic according to the IHRA definition due to its potential to stigmatize Jewish individuals through specific norms and practices.
JDA_Explanation:
The tweet urging Jews in Germany to wear a kippa and reveal their identity does not constitute antisemitism according to the Jerusalem Declaration on Antisemitism (JDA). 

1. **Repetition of Jewish Practice**: Wearing a kippa is a traditional religious observance for many Jews, and promoting this practice is not inherently discriminatory or hostile.

2. **Identity Revelation**: The instruction to "not conceal identity" suggests respect rather than discrimination. It does not generalize about all Jews but is a specific advisory based on the U.S. ambassador's guidance.

3. **Lack of Essentialization**: There is no evidence in the tweet that treats Jews as a homogeneous group with inherent characteristics, which is a key aspect of antisemitism defined by the JDA.

4. **Contextual Nature**: The tweet does not imply broader conspiracies or negative associations about Jews without specific context, avoiding coded language typical in antisemitic rhetoric.

Thus, the tweet respects individual choices and religious practices, aligning with principles of equality and respect outlined in the JDA guidelines.

Text: I do think such revisionism is anti-Semitic because it entirely denies the slaughter of Jews at the hands of Palestinian Arabs, goaded on with the support of Hitler. https://t.co/dxP6oT2hni
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet exhibits antisemitic characteristics as per the IHRA definition by employing revisionism to deny factual inaccuracies about the Holocaust and targeting Jewish people or associations with them (e.g., Palestinian Arabs) while associating these groups with historical atrocities committed under false Hitler's support. This use of negative stereotypes and denial of factual harm done to Jews aligns with antisemitic practices, making the tweet antisemitic according to IHRA standards.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet does not explicitly equate the denial of the Holocaust to an inherent antisemitic stereotype or use external factors (like Hitler's support) as a basis for anti-Semitism against Jews themselves. Instead, it states that revisionism is anti-Semitic because it denies the slaughter of Jews and was influenced by external causes, which do not inherently tie the act to a Jewish people. Therefore, according to the JDA guidelines, this tweet does not constitute antisemitism.

Text: Doctor Who Worked at Cleveland Clinic Said She‚Äôd Give ‚Äúthe Wrong Meds‚Äù to Jews\nhttps://t.co/U8phESrifP
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet in question does not meet the criteria for antisemitism as defined by the International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance (IHRA). Antisemitism involves hatred, discrimination, or negative perceptions directed toward Jews, often expressed through speech, writing, visual forms, or actions that employ harmful stereotypes. This tweet merely makes a speculative claim about a doctor providing incorrect medications to individuals referred to as "Jews." It does not exhibit any overtly hateful language, nor does it imply or target Jews in a way that aligns with the IHRA's definition of antisemitism. While it could be seen as indirectly targeting a specific group, there is no clear evidence of intent to harm, discriminate, or spread harmful stereotypes about Jews based on their identity alone.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet does not exhibit characteristics of antisemitism under the Jerusalem Declaration's definition. It makes a factual claim about a possible medical error without any indication of bias against Jews or discrimination based on ethnicity. There is no mention of prejudice, hostility, or denial of rights specific to Jewish individuals, making it non-antisemitic in nature.

Text: @AlanDersh @DanFeinreich @nytimes Now do trump calling both neo-Nazis chanting ‚ÄúJews will not replace us‚Äù and the people that oppose them ‚Äúfine people.‚Äù \n\nBecause if a cartoon is indicative of anti-Semitism, then complimenting a group of people literally screaming Nazi slogans is indicative of pure hatred.
IHRA_Explanation:
The tweet employs a quote from neo-Nazis ("Jews will not replace us") and labels those opposing them as "fine people." This aligns with antisemitic stereotypes that dehumanize non-Jewish groups, using negative language to perpetuate hatred. While the tweet doesn't directly target Jews but uses harmful language consistent with antisemitism by implying non-Jews are inferior or evil without valid basis.

The IHRA considers such behavior as antisemitic because it employs stereotypes and negative character traits that dehumanize Jewish people or their perceived enemies, aligning with the definition provided.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet contains elements that could touch on antisemitism but does not fully meet the criteria as defined by the JDA. While it references an anti-Semitic slogan ("Jews will not replace us"), which is itself an expression of antisemitic ideology, the use of general labels like "fine people" without specific context or justification risks essentializing a group and contributing to stereotyping. However, since the tweet does not explicitly apply these labels in a discriminatory manner beyond referencing anti-Semitism, it may not fully align with the JDA's definition of antisemitism as involving systematic discrimination or hostility against Jews.

Text: @Blisz2 @C_Oranye @renoomokri That's always the plan tho üòÇ.\n\nBut my theory is that the early Jews were Arabs too
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet is antisemitic according to the IHRA definition because it implies that early Jews were similar to Arabs, suggesting a negative stereotype about Jews. This stereotype could lead to discrimination and denial of opportunities for Jewish individuals, aligning with the IHRA's criteria for antisemitism involving harmful generalizations or denials about Jewish people.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet uses a stereotype where the speaker attributes all early Jews to being Arabs. This is problematic because it essentializes Jews into a negative category based on a stereotypical assumption, which aligns with General guideline 1 of the JDA. Essentializing groups leads to discrimination and can perpetuate harmful stereotypes about Jews. Therefore, this tweet does not meet the criteria for antisemitism as defined by the JDA guidelines.

Text: As pointed out in this article, Jewish leaders and educators need to do more to expose White Jews to the reality of Jews of Color and teach ppl not to question a fellow Jew just because they look different. https://t.co/yVDqkq0kXN
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet discusses the importance of educating White Jews about the reality of other Jewish communities, including Jews of Color. This focus is on promoting understanding and diversity without targeting any specific group negatively. There are no elements that align with the IHRA definition of antisemitism, which involves hatred or negative perceptions towards Jews. Instead, it addresses educational practices aimed at fostering a more inclusive society.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet does not adhere to the definition or guidelines of antisemitism as outlined in the JDA. It discusses educational practices aimed at promoting diversity and inclusivity within the Jewish community, specifically targeting White Jews by encouraging them to learn about Jews of Color. This approach is about understanding and respecting different perspectives within Judaism rather than perpetuating any form of discrimination, prejudice, or harmful generalizations about Jewish individuals or communities. The tweet does not reference any form of antisemitic stereotypes, denigrations, or historical conspiracies that are central to antisemitism according to the JDA guidelines.

Text: And WTH is the #GOP? If they think any Jews or people of color (or Danes) will EVER trust them again after their silence on all this - they are sorely mistaken.
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet contains several elements that align with antisemitic themes. It references "Jews" in a context that could perpetuate stereotypes, suggesting that the GOP's silence on issues involving Jews may stem from their perceived untrustworthiness or conspiratorial leanings. Additionally, by implying that non-Jewish groups like people of color and Danes won't share this trust either, it extends beyond antisemitism to a broader form of discrimination against minorities. While the primary focus is on Jews, the tweet's use of negative language and stereotypes aligns with the IHRA's criteria for antisemitism, particularly in how it targets specific groups based on their identity.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet employs stereotyping by labeling specific groups‚ÄîJews and people of color‚Äîas untrustworthy, which aligns with the Jerusalem Declaration's definition of antisemitism as it involves essentializing traits against a population based on prejudice. This approach lacks nuance and generalizes about individual characteristics without considering their diversity or context.

Text: We Can No Longer Ignore the Attacks on Jews in New York @realDonaldTrump @michellemalkin @IngrahamAngle @seanhannity @marklevinshow @larryelder @MonicaCrowley - via @FreedomWatchUSA https://t.co/2SpLtxkCJ4
IHRA_Explanation:
The tweet expresses concern about an attack on Jews and cites conservative news figures, reflecting solidarity rather than engaging in harmful or discriminatory language. It does not exhibit any of the IHRA's definitions of antisemitism, such as hatred, stereotypes, or blame for real or imagined wrongdoing.

The tweet is not antisemitic according to the IHRA definition because it does not express hatred towards Jews or use any negative stereotypes. Instead, it conveys concern and solidarity against an attack on Jewish people.
JDA_Explanation:
The tweet addresses attacks on Jews in New York generally without targeting specific individuals or making any statements that would be considered discrimination or prejudice against Jewish people. It is an expression of concern and a reaction to incidents, not an antisemitic statement.

The tweet does not reference any antisemitic guidelines outlined in the JDA, such as essentializing Jews, making negative generalizations about a population, or linking Jews to harmful ideas. Instead, it is a straightforward declaration of concern for victims without incorporating any antisemitic stereotypes, caricatures, or coded language typical of antisemitism.

Furthermore, there are no references to anti-Semitic principles like the denial of the Holocaust, support for Israelis, or systematic discrimination based on race. The tweet does not fit within any category of antisemitic expressions as defined by the JDA. It is important to note that while addressing any form of hate speech requires care, this particular tweet falls short of meeting the criteria for being considered antisemitic.

In summary, the tweet is a normal and reasonable statement about the suffering experienced by Jewish people in New York, without engaging in or promoting any antisemitic ideas.

Text: ‚ÄúShe (Congresswoman Omar) keeps on assaulting Jews...‚Äù \nJeff Ballabon, B2 Strategic, CEO https://t.co/WMKN9RQm2n
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet in question uses negative language to describe Congresswoman Omar's actions toward Jews in general, but without specific context or mention of her Jewish identity, it does not explicitly target an individual. While it could be interpreted as implying hatred against the Jewish community, the absence of direct personal targeting makes it less clear-cut as antisemitic under IHRA's definition compared to a statement that specifically targets an individual named as Jewish.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet uses broad and potentially discriminatory language ("keeps on assaulting Jews") that could be interpreted as targeting Jewish individuals specifically, aligning with the JDA's definition of antisemitism. This statement may generalize behavior towards Jews without providing specific justification, contributing to stigmatization or discrimination against the group.

Text: @Ursula1781 @gabeschoenfeld @RJC Wait wait wait...please tell me I‚Äôm misunderstanding the ‚Äúrich Jews in Germany...‚Äù part. Are we now victim-blaming for the Holocaust? Something tells me the WASPY American 1% won‚Äôt find themselves in concentration camps or gas chambers, mass graves, or incinerators.
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet employs stereotypical language by comparing "rich Jews in Germany" to WASPy Americans, suggesting that Jews are being victimized without justification. This aligns with the IHRA's definition of antisemitism, which includes using stereotypes and potentially demonizing a group based on characteristics linked to Jewish heritage. By framing Jews as victims, it reinforces negative stereotypes and could be seen as antisemitic in nature.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet exhibits antisemitism by employing a stereotype where rich Jews are associated with historical atrocities through economic status. It implies that because Rich Jews in Germany were spared during the Holocaust compared to other groups, they should now be blamed retroactively for it. This uses economic class as a negative stereotype linked to victimhood, essentializing Jews based on this trait without evidence. Such reasoning aligns with antisemitic practices by making broad generalizations about Jewish people, treating them as a homogeneous group burdened with historical wrongdoings tied to their economic background.

Text: @JGreenblattADL @POTUS Who among his cult has taken his words to heart and also happens to have assault weapons? Jews are now targets for more hate crimes like Mexicans, immigrants, POC, women, #LGBTQ. We haven‚Äôt forgotten Pittsburgh and Poway. His rhetoric is racist, misogynistic and anti Semitic.
IHRA_Explanation:
The tweet explicitly labels the POTUS's rhetoric as "anti Semitic" and mentions targeting Jews in relation to other groups like Mexicans, immigrants, POC, women, and LGBTQ+ individuals. This aligns with IHRA's definition of antisemitism by using negative terms directed toward Jews.

The tweet's mention of anti Semitic rhetoric directly references the IHRA's working definition, which includes the use of negative character traits or stereotypes against Jews. Additionally, it implies a discriminatory targeting of Jews, consistent with antisemitic behavior defined by IHRA. Therefore, this tweet meets the criteria for being antisemitic under the provided definition.
JDA_Explanation:
The tweet is antisemitic according to the Jerusalem Declaration on Antisemitism (JDA). It employs harmful stereotypes by equating Jews with groups like Mexicans, immigrants, people of color, women, and LGBTQ+ individuals in terms of hate crimes. Additionally, it labels his rhetoric as racist, misogynistic, and anti-Semitic, which aligns with JDA guidelines that define antisemitism through discrimination, prejudice, and harmful generalizations about Jews or Jewish institutions.

The tweet uses terms like "his cult" to refer to Jewish leaders without justification, reinforcing the stereotype of Jews as a cohesive target group. While it may lack specific examples of hate crimes against Trump or targeted instances involving Jews, the use of broad, derogatory language still constitutes antisemitism by essentializing and generalizing about Jewish people.

Text: Today is my father's yahrzeit. We are ex-Soviet Jews. "Nationaility" was the "fifth column." Look it up. Both of us lived through some horrifying antisemitism that included physical violence. Your Jewish "nationality" was stated in all your documents.
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet in question is a personal recount of the author's father's death and their own identification as ex-Soviet Jews, along with an anecdote about their experience of being labeled as part of a "fifth column" due to their Jewish nationality. This narrative does not generalize or broadly accuse Jews of hatred or antisemitism but rather reflects on specific past experiences without targeting the entire Jewish community. Therefore, it does not meet the criteria for antisemitism as defined by the IHRA, which involves directed hatred or discrimination against Jews either as a group or individuals beyond personal recounting.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet does not directly use terms that fit under JDA's definition of antisemitism. While it alludes to a fifth column and discusses antisemitism, the context is personal and does not generalize or target a population. Without explicit use of negative stereotypes or coded language against Jews, it doesn't meet the criteria for antisemitic content as per the guidelines provided.

Text: At a time when the @JewishChron asks non-Jews to appreciate the fears of the Jewish community, it then publishes as disgusting piece denying the right of Muslims to fear hatred against themselves. Sorry @stephenpollard  this is just not on
IHRA_Explanation:
The tweet does not directly target specific Jewish individuals or groups with hatred or discrimination. Instead, it critiques a societal response (The Jewish Chron) to fears about the Jewish community and draws an analogy between non-Jewish concerns and those of Muslims regarding fear of hatred. While it may perpetuate stereotypes, it does not specifically meet the IHRA's definition of antisemitism, which requires direct harm or perception towards Jews.

However, upon closer inspection, this tweet could be seen as reinforcing negative stereotypes about Jewish communities by comparing their fears to those of other groups, potentially contributing to stigmatization. Yet, according to the strict criteria, it doesn't explicitly target Jews or express hatred toward them. Therefore, it does not fully align with IHRA's definition.

Final decision: No
JDA_Explanation: The tweet does not directly address antisemitic content but rather makes a general statement about the Jewish community's fears, which might inadvertently touch on stereotypes. However, it doesn't use discriminatory language, symbols, or references typical of antisemitism as defined by the JDA. The criticism seems more of a personal critique without overtly targeting Jews or using stereotypical language.

Text: 1) BREAKING: Shooter at #SanDiego synagogue appears to be a white supremacist who described his hate for Jews & others in a letter. States he was inspired by #NewZealand shooter Brenton Tarrant and urges fellow white supremacists to carry out their own attacks. https://t.co/rulXZbv7xh
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet is considered antisemitic according to the IHRA's definition because it references a white supremacist who expressed hatred toward Jews, uses the term "white supremacist" which is a derogatory label for a group associated with antisemitism, and normalizes violent acts by comparing them to someone else known for promoting such behavior. These actions involve targeting Jewish people based on negative stereotypes and glorifying hate crimes against them.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet describes an incident where a white supremacist expressed hatred towards Jews in a letter. However, under the JDA guidelines, antisemitism involves systematic discrimination or prejudice against the entire Jewish population. This tweet does not generalize or consistently apply antisemitic principles; it focuses on an individual act rather than broader targeting of the Jewish community as a whole.

Text: So much antisemitic hatred in one video...\n\nAs Jews celebrate #Passover, #antisemitic residents of the town of Pruchnik in southern #Poland beat and burned a doll made to represent a Jew with stereotypical features. https://t.co/3Hl0GbCtmd
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet depicts residents of Pruchnik in southern Poland beating and burning a doll representing a Jew. This act directly targets a Jewish individual, using stereotypical features to demonize Jews. According to the IHRA definition, antisemitism involves targeting individuals or property based on their Jewishness, including through physical harm or speech that uses negative stereotypes. Therefore, this tweet exemplifies antisemitic behavior by expressing hatred and using stereotyping towards Jews.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet in question contains elements that align with the Jerusalem Declaration on Antisemitism (JDA). Specifically, it references an act of violence directed at a representation of a Jew, which is a form of antisemitic behavior as defined by the JDA. The tweet implies a stereotype that Jews are being targeted for their identity without providing context about the video's content beyond its association with antisemitic acts. This stereotyping and violence against a community's members constitute antisemitism under the provided guidelines.

Text: @RayPoetry Bless you Ray, the violence towards Christians and Jews just breaks my heart!
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet explicitly mentions "Jews" in the context of violence, which aligns with the IHRA definition that involves directing hatred or expression towards Jewish individuals. While the tweet also includes a mention of Christians and shows compassion toward Ray, the inclusion of Jews and their portrayal as victims of violence makes it antisemitic under the given criteria.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet does not qualify as antisemitic according to the JDA. It expresses compassion towards those affected by violence affecting both Jews and Christians without targeting Jews specifically with any form of discrimination or prejudice.

Text: Netanyahu first said that Israel is the nation-state of the Jews only and now he says that Palestinians in Israel have 22 countries to go to. This is exactly what Apartheid leaders in South Africa said in relation to non- whites. It was abhorrent then and abhorrent now.
IHRA_Explanation:
The tweet does not explicitly target Jews or their community institutions and properties. While the analogy drawn is about racial oppression, it is a general comment on historical events without specifically targeting Jews or implying harm to Jewish individuals or groups.

The IHRA definition of antisemitism requires specific targeting of Jews or their communities in terms of hatred, stereotypes, or discrimination. The tweet does not meet these criteria as it does not directly target Jews or their properties but instead uses a general analogy about historical events unrelated to antisemitism. Therefore, the tweet is not considered antisemitic according to the IHRA definition.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet does not explicitly accuse or essentialize non-Israeli Jews but makes an analogy between Netanyahu's historical remarks about Israel being the nation-state of Jews and Apartheid leaders. While this comparison could imply support for Apartheid-like actions, the tweet is neutral in context and does not directly attribute such actions to Netanyahu. Therefore, it does not meet the criteria for antisemitism as defined by essentializing a group or making an unsupported accusation against them.

Text: Equating support for Israel with support for Jews is anti-Semitic.
IHRA_Explanation:
The tweet equates supporting Israel with supporting Jews, which targets individual Jewish people outside of Israel's territory. This generalization reduces the value of specific Jewish communities and perpetuates harmful stereotypes. According to IHRA, this aligns with antisemitic ideologies by targeting a group as a whole rather than individuals within it, thereby denying them their right to self-determination or equivalence in support.

**Step-by-Step Explanation:**

1. **Targeting a Group:** The tweet associates support for Israel with support for Jews broadly, affecting any Jewish person not necessarily tied to Israel.
   
2. **Stereotyping:** It simplifies support for Jews by tying it exclusively to support for Israel, creating a biased stereotype about Jewish individuals.

3. **Denying Self-Determination:** By equating support for Israel with support for Jews, it implicitly denies other Jewish people their right to self-determination beyond the state of Israel.

4. **Breadth of Targeting:** The tweet's impact extends beyond Israel, affecting all Jewish communities worldwide, thus aligning with antisemitic principles that target a group rather than individuals within it.

Thus, the tweet is considered antisemitic as it marginalizes Jewish people and aligns with IHRA's definition by targeting them as a whole.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet equates support for Israel with support for Jews, which aligns with the JDA's definition of antisemitism as discrimination against Jews. This association implies that supporting a state equates to supporting a specific ethnic group within it, akin to point 7 where Jews are held collectively responsible for the nation's actions. Additionally, it references point 6 by applying negative stereotypes or associations to a state, thereby reinforcing antisemitic biases. Thus, this tweet is anti-Semitic according to JDA guidelines.

Text: @MichaelRosenYes Jews in the Labour Party are perfectly safe - unless they support Palestine/criticise Israel/support Jeremy Corbyn - in which case they will often be attacked by people like Louise Ellman. The Labour Party is a safer place for Jewish comrades without her. https://t.co/NmqOH0iSjd
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet in question employs language and targeting that aligns with aspects of antisemitism according to the IHRA definition. It suggests that Jews within the Labour Party are unsafe unless they support specific policies, such as Jeremy Corbyn or criticizing Israel. By implying that certain Labour members will be attacked due to their political stances‚Äîsimilar to how the Nazis perceived the Jewish community‚Äîthe tweet engages in a form of antisemitic ideology by using negative associations and conflating individual actions with broader group targets without explicitly singling out all Jews. This approach inadvertently reflects harmful stereotypes, contributing to the categorization as antisemitic.
JDA_Explanation:
The tweet is not antisemitic as it does not meet any of the criteria outlined in the Jerusalem Declaration on Antisemitism (JDA). 

1. **Essentialization**: The tweet does not essentialize Jews into having negative outcomes based on their party or views. It suggests that being part of Labour and supporting Corbyn could lead to personal attacks, which is different from stigmatizing an entire group.

2. **Linking to Evil**: There is no suggestion in the tweet linking Jews directly to evil or forces of harm through supporting Palestine or criticizing Israel.

3. **Word, Image, Deed**: The tweet does not use words that could be interpreted as antisemitic or portray negative stereotypes about Jews.

4. **Direct/Indirect, Explicit/Coded**: While it mentions potential attacks on supporters of Corbyn, this is framed within a political context and does not explicitly use coded language typical of antisemitism.

5. **Denying Holocaust**: The tweet does not touch on any issues related to denial or denial of the Holocaust.

Thus, the tweet avoids the elements of antisemitism as defined by the JDA.

Text: Whipping up the fury of the Iranian masses against Saudi Arabia, the Jews and the great Satan. https://t.co/YB889J4cqx

This expression of hatred toward Jews fits within IHRA's definition of antisemitism, which includes using negative and dehumanizing language towards Jewish individuals or groups.

It targets several entities‚ÄîIranian masses, Saudi Arabia, and the great Satan‚Äîas sources of fury, with "Jews" being merely one component of that list. Since there's no indication of negative connotation beyond their inclusion, it does not meet JDA's criteria for antisemitism.

Text: @jonathanglennie @DAaronovitch Dear Jews, please look past the Antisemitism and vote labour. Next week, Dear BAMEs, look past the violent racists and vote BNP (if they still exist!!)
IHRA_Explanation:
<think>
Okay, so I need to figure out if the tweet is antisemitic according to the IHRA definition. Let me start by reading the tweet again:

"@jonathanglennie @DAaronovitch Dear Jews, please look past the Antisemitism and vote Labour. Next week, Dear BAMEs, look past the violent racists and vote BNP (if they still exist!!)"

First, I'll break down what's being said here. The tweet is directed at Jewish people ("Dear Jews") and Black and Asian Minority Ethnic (BAME) individuals ("Dear BAMEs"). It tells them to ignore antisemitism or racism and vote for Labour and the BNP respectively.

Now, looking at the IHRA definition: Antisemitism involves hatred towards Jews, expressed in various ways. This tweet specifically targets Jews by name and tells them not to be affected by what it refers to as "antisemitism." It also targets BAMEs by their perceived race group and advises them to vote for a different political party due to racism.

The IHRA definition includes targeting individuals or groups based on their perceived characteristics, which this tweet does. The language used is about looking past issues related to antisemitism or racism to make voting decisions. This could be seen as reinforcing stereotypes by labeling a group (Jews) as problematic and another (antisemitism) as the issue.

Moreover, it's using terms like "BAMEs" which are derogatory, contributing to negative perceptions of certain groups. The call to vote based on these perceived issues aligns with antisemitic behavior where group stereotypes are used to target specific communities for discrimination or hostility.

So putting this together, yes, the tweet is antisemitic because it uses targeted language against Jews and BAMEs, reinforcing negative stereotypes and instructing them to be affected by what it perceives as their group's issues. This fits within the IHRA's definition of antisemitism.
</think>

DECISION: Yes

The tweet is antisemitic according to the IHRA definition because it explicitly targets Jewish individuals ("Dear Jews") and Black and Asian Minority Ethnic groups ("Dear BAMEs") by using derogatory language and reinforcing negative stereotypes. It directs these groups to vote against Labour and the BNP, respectively, based on perceived issues related to antisemitism or racism. This behavior aligns with the IHRA's criteria for antisemitism, as it involves directing hatred and discrimination against specific communities through speech and instruction.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet does not explicitly use anti-Semitic stereotypes or language targeting Jews. It instead advises voters to look past perceived negative traits related to antisemitism for specific political parties. While it encourages understanding of these issues, it does not directly promote or endorse harmful ideologies that could incite hatred against Jewish individuals. Therefore, according to the JDA's guidelines, this tweet is not considered antisemitic as it does not involve discrimination, prejudice, or negative generalizations about a population.

Text: Dear @UKLabour Jews in this video do NOT recognise the State of Israel on RELIGIOUS grounds.  Would Labour Party Expel if any of these Jews were members of Labour Party and expressed such religious views.  This is a Legal Question. https://t.co/3y95yy884Q
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet raises concerns about religious discrimination against Jews by questioning whether individuals who do not recognize the State of Israel on religious grounds would be expelled from the Labour Party. While it touches on a sensitive issue that could perpetuate negative stereotypes, it does not explicitly target Jews or express hatred toward them based on their Jewish identity. Instead, it addresses a broader issue of religious beliefs within a professional context, which may not meet the specific criteria of antisemitism as defined by IHRA.
JDA_Explanation:
The tweet raises concerns under the Jerusalem Declaration on Antisemitism (JDA) for several reasons:

1. **Religious Grounds and Jewish Identity**: The tweet discusses recognition of the State of Israel based on religious grounds, which could be interpreted as denying a Jewish people's right to their own religious and national identity in an internationally recognized context.

2. **Negative Stereotypes and Denial**: By implying that holding certain religious views would lead to expulsion from Labour Party, it might target individuals based on religion or beliefs without a basis of widespread discrimination elsewhere.

3. **Potential Double Standard**: The tweet could be seen as applying a double standard if such religious views are not widely held outside the Jewish community, thereby potentially labeling them as harmful when they don't align with broader societal norms.

4. **Political Affiliation and Religion**: The hypothetical nature of expulsion ties political affiliations to religion, which may cross into antisemitism by targeting specific groups based on faith or identity rather than individual beliefs.

Given these points, the tweet could be considered antisemitic as it relates to Jewish identity and religiously informed views that may impact perceptions of discrimination.

Text: Jews & Gentiles both running over the course of this world: the Jews using the written law, the Gentiles using the law of nature. Or, they were both running by their natural desire for happiness and for a knowledge of the truth, which all men desire to know by their very nature https://t.co/rVAC03UubI
IHRA_Explanation:
The tweet does not exhibit any form of antisemitism as per the IHRA definition. It discusses a philosophical and religious topic without any references to hatred, discrimination, or negative behavior directed toward Jews or Jewish communities. The content is neutral and factual, focusing on contrasting approaches to law rather than targeting specific groups negatively.

The tweet's message is about different methods of living and understanding truth, not about attacking or prejudicing any particular group. Therefore, it does not meet the criteria for being antisemitic under IHRA standards.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet does not exhibit antisemitic behavior according to the Jerusalem Declaration on Antisemitism (JDA). It presents a neutral comparison between the legal systems and approaches to life taken by Jews and Gentiles. There is no essentialization, denigration, or application of anti-Semitic symbols or stereotypes. The discussion remains focused on different methods for living rather than any discriminatory claims against Jews.

Text: Two reported killed during synagogue shooting at Halle, Germany, on Yom Kippur, the Jews‚Äô holiest day.  https://t.co/gI18eu5Jmf
IHRA_Explanation:
The tweet in question is not antisemitic according to the International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance (IHRA) definition. It reports a tragic event involving a synagogue where two people were killed on Yom Kippur, which is a significant Jewish holiday. The tweet accurately describes the event without any overtly antisemitic language or stereotypes. It does not exhibit any form of hatred, bias, or generalization directed toward Jews as a group. Instead, it reflects a tragic incident directly related to the Jewish community, causing distress but not fulfilling the criteria for antisemitism outlined by IHRA.

The tweet is merely an update about what happened and does not engage in any form of discrimination or harmful rhetoric against Jews. It could evoke emotional distress for those affected or their communities, but it does not meet the legal, speech, or action-based definitions of antisemitism set forth by IHRA.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet does not exhibit antisemitism according to the Jerusalem Declaration on Antisemitism (JDA). It simply reports an event involving a synagogue shooting on Yom Kippur, Germany's holiest day. While the mention of Yom Kippur might evoke associations with Jewish communities, the tweet itself does not contain any statements or coded messages targeting Jews or express any form of antisemitic bias. The JDA focuses on discrimination, prejudice, or hostility towards Jews as a group, but this tweet is merely an objective description of an event without such elements.
